{{coord|31|57|5|S|141|26|25|E|type:landmark_scale:2000|name=BKN}} }} [[File:GTSBKN Broken Hill studios.jpg|thumb|right|GTS/BKN studios in Broken Hill]] '''GTS/BKN''', known on-air as '''Southern Cross Television''', is an [[Australia]]n [[television station]] based in [[Port Pirie, South Australia|Port Pirie]]. It broadcasts throughout [[South Australia|South Australia's]] [[Spencer Gulf]] and in [[Broken Hill, New South Wales|Broken Hill]]. The station's name originates from the original [[Port Pirie, South Australia|Port Pirie]] & [[Broken Hill, New South Wales|Broken Hill]] stations callsigns, '''GTS''' in [[Port Pirie, South Australia|Port Pirie]] and '''BKN''' in [[Broken Hill, New South Wales|Broken Hill]], [[New South Wales]]. ==History== In [[1974]], the stations (and their repeaters) joined to become Spencer Gulf Telecasters and broadcast under the name ''Central GTS/BKN''. The company has since been bought by [[Southern Cross Broadcasting]] (SCB), though it retained the Central name until the end of [[2005]]. In [[2003]], Spencer Gulf Telecasters won the right to broadcast a second station in the same area, and in January 2004 started broadcasting [[Southern Cross Ten]]. In January [[2006]] Central GTS/BKN was renamed ''Southern Cross GTS/BKN'', changing its logo to the same one currently used by [[Southern Cross Tasmania]] and [[TND-34|Southern Cross Darwin]]. The Southern Cross Ten logo was also updated to the current logo used by SC 10 stations elsewhere. ===Digital Television=== {{Expand section|Details on digital TV switch-on in Spencer Gulf/Broken Hill|date=June 2011}} In line with the Federal Government's timetable for switching off the analogue television signal, Broken Hill and the Spencer Gulf regions switched off its analogue signal on 15 December 2010.Australian Government. [http://www.digitalready.gov.au/when-do-i-switch/Rollout-map/South-Australia.aspx Digital TV Switchover Australia - South Australia]. Accessed on 5 June 2011. Prior to the analogue television switchover, GTS/BKN launched a Nine affiliate as a digital-only channel, branded ''Southern Cross Nine'', on 31 October 2010, followed by the Ten Network's Eleven in January 2011.Southern Cross Media Group. [http://www.gtsbkn.com.au/ Southern Cross GTS/BKN Television]. Accessed on 5 June 2011. Southern Cross Austereo has announced that the additional digital signals for Spencer Gulf and Broken Hill markets are on track for launch at the end of 2011. 7Two, 7Mate, Go!, GEM and One are part of the digital TV roll out and are expected to be on air in November and December 2011 in majority of the Spencer gulf region. ==Programming== Southern Cross GTS/BKN broadcasts [[Seven Network]] programming, Southern Cross Nine broadcasts [[Nine Network]] programming, Southern Cross Ten broadcasts [[Network Ten]] programming. ===News=== In line with the name change, GTS/BKN's 30-minute regional news bulletin, ''Central News'', was revamped and renamed ''Southern Cross News''. This bulletin is broadcast on Southern Cross GTS/BKN at 6.30pm, after ''[[Seven News]]'' on weeknights. Therefore, Seven's Today Tonight is not shown in the region.
